components.label: HTML
components.content:
Animals and pests

Animals and pests can:

  • contaminate surfaces, equipment and food
  • transfer bacteria from their bodies onto anything they touch.

Guide dogs and other assistance animals are allowed in any area used by customers. Assistance animals are defined by the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 (Cth).

Only dogs are allowed in outdoor dining areas if you as the business choose to allow them. Check with your local council for the rules that apply in your area.

Before you start

To complete this topic you will need to think about how you:

  • prevent pests
  • manage animals at your food business

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Animals and pests

* Do you stop pests from entering your food business

Ways to stop pests may include:

  • flyscreens on windows and doors
  • seal any holes, cracks or gaps in ceilings, walls, floors or around pipes etc.
  • remove waste regularly
  • keep your food business clean, inside and outside.

components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Regular inspection and maintenance of your premises helps to stop pests entering your food business.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may become contaminated from pests. Pests must be stopped from entering your premises. Keeping a clean business will also help to discourage pests.

For tips on how to stop pests, see the Controlling Pests factsheet at the end of this topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content: * Do you have regular pest control done to remove pests?

components.label: Do you have regular pest control done to remove pests?.
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Remember to check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs) between treatments. Call your technician if you need extra treatment.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may become contaminated.

Consider these actions:

  • Have regular pest control done and keep receipts for each time it is done.
  • Regularly check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs).

For tips on how to stop pests, see the Controlling Pests factsheet at the end of this topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content: * Do animals enter food handling areas?

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

They may contaminate food and surfaces.

The only live animals that you can have include:

  • fish in decorative tanks
  • live seafood for sale.

If you keep live animals, you will need to have food safety processes in place to keep and handle the live animals. For example:

  • protect food handling areas when you clean fish tanks
  • clean tanks using equipment that is not used to prepare food
  • practice good hand hygiene after handling the animals.

Further information can be found on the web page listed at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Well done

Animals (other than live seafood for sale, or decorative fish tanks) are not allowed in areas where you handle food.

components.label: HTML
components.content: * Do you allow animals in outdoor dining areas?

components.label: Do you allow animals in outdoor dining areas?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Only dogs are the allowed in outdoor dining areas.

Remember:

  • It is your choice to allow dogs into your outdoor areas.
  • You are responsible for making sure they do not contaminate any part of your premises.
  • You must allow assistance animals in all customer areas. Assistance animals are registered animals (e.g.: guide dogs) and do not include pets or companion animals.

To find out more about the responsibilities you and your customers must follow when allowing dogs in outdoor dining areas, see the webpage content provided at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Did you know?

You can choose to allow dogs in outdoor dining areas.

Remember, assistance animals are allowed in all customer areas. Assistance animals are registered animals (e.g.: guide dogs) and do not include pets or companion animals.

Further information about the responsibilities you and your customers must follow can be found at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Summary

Thank you for taking the time to complete the Animals and pests self-assessment.

A self-assessment summary has been generated from your responses to each question. From this page you can:

  • View resources for more information about this topic
  • Download a summary of your self-assessment
  • Email a summary of your self-assessment
  • Start another next self-assessment topic

Contact your local council if you would like further information or resources for your food business

Resources

Below is a list of resources that you can view for more information about this topic.

Controlling pests

Key information on controlling pests in a food business and practical tips to reduce food safety risks.

Download factsheet (PDF, 121 KB)

Pest management

Appendix 7 from Safe Food Australia with additional information referred to in the Controlling Pests factsheet.

Download guideline (PDF, 40 KB)

Animals in food premises

Information about the legislative requirements for animals in food business including definitions, tips for maintaining food safety standards and customer responsibilities.

Go to website

Your self-assessment summary

Download your self-assessment summary.

components.content:
If you prefer, we can send you your self-assessment summary by providing an email address below.

Email

Depending on your email provider, personal information may be transferred outside of Australia. By providing your email address, you voluntarily agree to this transfer.

Topics to complete

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Health and hygiene

Food safety is the responsibility of both the owner of a business and all staff employed at the business.

As a food business, you are responsible for making sure that staff are provided with a way to wash their hands. Handwashing is an easy way to prevent cross contamination.

Food handlers who are sick can infect surfaces and customers food. It is the responsibility of both the food business and food handlers to not handle or deliver food when unwell.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • Have employees been told about their health and hygiene duties?
  • Do you make sure that sick employees do not handle or go near food?
  • Have staff been told about when and how often to wash their hands?
  • Can staff access hand washing basins at all times?
  • Does your hand wash basin have warm running water, soap, paper towels and a bin (or air dryer)?

components.label: HTML
components.content:

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Health and hygiene

components.legend: Does each hand wash basin have:
components.label: Does each hand wash basin have:
HTML
components.content:
• warm running water
  • soap
  • single use towel or other method to dry hands
  • bin for used towels

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Well done

To help remind staff, posters are available at the end of the topic in the food safety resource kits.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand washing is very important to prevent contamination in your food business.

You must have warm running water, soap, single use towels (or air dryer) and a bin at your hand washing basin. It is better to use liquid soap as bar soap and soap dishes can become contaminated.

Hand gels and sanitisers should not be used instead of soap and water.

Resources on how and when to wash hands are included in the food safety resource kits at the end of the topic. We recommend you share these resources with your staff.

components.legend: Do staff use the hand wash basins for other kitchen tasks?
components.label: Do staff use the hand wash basins for other kitchen tasks?
HTML
components.content:
For example, to:
  • rinse dishes
  • rinse fruit and vegetables
  • fill up a mop bucket

components.label: Do staff use the hand wash basins for other kitchen tasks?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand wash basins must only be used to wash hands, arms and face. Hand wash basins may become contaminated if you use the hand wash basin for other kitchen tasks.

It needs to be clear to staff that the basins are only for washing hands. This can be done by putting up signs or pictures showing hand washing.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.legend: Do staff know how and when to:
components.label: Do staff know how and when to:
HTML
components.content:
• wash hands
  • change gloves

components.label: Do staff know how and when to:
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Hand washing plays a very important role to stop food poisoning. Gloves must be changed between tasks where you would normally wash your hands.

To help remind staff, posters are available in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand washing is very important to stop food poisoning. Food handlers must wash their hands:

  • when their hands may be contaminated (e.g.: after handling raw meat, after taking out the rubbish)
  • before handling food
  • after using the toilet, smoking, coughing, sneezing, eating, drinking or touching their face or head.

Gloves must be changed between tasks where you would normally wash your hands.

Resources on how and when to wash hands are included in the food safety resource kits at the end of the topic. We recommend you share these resources with your staff.

components.legend: Do staff cover open wounds and sores?
components.label: Do staff cover open wounds and sores?
Do staff cover open wounds and sores?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Weeping from a wound can contaminate food and surfaces. All wounds or sores on an exposed part of the body must be covered with a waterproof covering such as a band-aid or bandage.

Brightly coloured dressings are recommended so they can be easily seen if they fall off.

components.legend: Do staff ensure that nothing from their body or clothing contaminates food?
components.label: Do staff ensure that nothing from their body or clothing contaminates food?
HTML
components.content: For example, nails, jewellery, clothing, hair, bandages, saliva, mucus or blood.

components.label: Do staff ensure that nothing from their body or clothing contaminates food?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Staff must not let anything from their body or clothing contaminate food or surfaces. This may cause harm to your customers.

The fact sheets at the end of the topic provide more information that you can share with your staff.

Alternatively, ask staff to complete the free online training DoFoodSafely which covers health and hygiene.

components.legend: Do you allow anyone to eat or smoke in the food handling areas?
components.label: Do you allow anyone to eat or smoke in the food handling areas?
Do you allow anyone to eat or smoke in the food handling areas?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Smoking and eating in food handling areas can contaminate food and equipment. This may cause harm to your customers and other staff.

The food business must make sure that people (who enter the premise) are not contaminating food, equipment or surfaces. This includes staff, tradespersons, visitors and customers.

You may wish to introduce a visitor log to identify who, when and why a person was in your premises. A sample template is included in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.legend: Do staff know not to cough, sneeze or spit on equipment,      surfaces or over food?
components.label: Do staff know not to cough, sneeze or spit on equipment,      surfaces or over food?
Do staff know not to cough, sneeze or spit on equipment, surfaces or over food?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Germs are spread by coughing, sneezing and spitting. By making sure staff know these requirements you reduce your risk of making a customer sick.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Germs are spread by coughing, sneezing and spitting. This may cause harm to your customers and other staff.

You need to let staff know the risks and legal requirements. You can give staff fact sheets at the end of the topic or you may choose to get them to complete the free online training program DoFoodSafely.

We recommend you keep a list of the training that you give to staff. A template log is included in the resources to help you.

components.legend: Are staff aware of their health and hygiene responsibilities, including when they are sick?
components.label: Are staff aware of their health and hygiene responsibilities, including when they are sick?
Are staff aware of their health and hygiene responsibilities, including when they are sick?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Staff can accidently contaminate food if they work when they are sick. This may cause harm to your customers and other staff.

The food business must tell all staff about their duties for:

  • good personal hygiene
  • illness
  • hand washing and
  • notifying their supervisor if they have, or think they have, contaminated food.

If the staff are from non-English-speaking backgrounds, the information should be provided in the relevant languages (if possible).

The free online training DoFoodSafely can help staff understand their duties and responsibilities. It is also available in other languages.

We recommend you keep a record of training provided. Template logs are available in the resources list to assist you.

components.legend: Do you have a staff illness procedure or policy?
components.label: Do you have a staff illness procedure or policy?
HTML
components.content:
For example: A procedure or policy that has rules such as:
  • when staff should not work
  • when they can start work again
  • how long should they stay away

components.label: Do you have a staff illness procedure or policy?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

By having a staff illness policy or procedure in place you are making sure staff and customers are not harmed by illness.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

A staff illness policy or procedure helps you to:

  • Manage staff when they are sick and when they are safe to work.
  • Reduce the risk of making other staff and customers sick.

We recommend that you:

  • Create a staff illness policy or procedure.
  • Give your policy or procedure to all staff.

If the staff are from non-English-speaking backgrounds, the information should be provided in the relevant languages (if possible).

components.legend: Do you keep a confidential log when staff are sick?
components.label: Do you keep a confidential log when staff are sick?
HTML
components.content: For example: personal diary entry

components.label: Do you keep a confidential log when staff are sick?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Keeping a log of staff illness helps you prove you are not responsible if a customer alleges food poisoning.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Keeping a log of staff illness helps you prove you are not responsible if a customer alleges food poisoning.

To help you improve food safety, a template register is provided in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you ensure any personal or medical information provided by a food handler     is kept confidential?
components.label: Field Set
HTML
components.content: For example: not tell anyone (such as other staff or customers) except those allowed by legislation.

components.label: Do you ensure any personal or medical information provided by a food handler is kept confidential?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Maintaining confidentiality encourages food handlers to report their illness quickly and assures them that the information will not be used for any purpose other than to protect food from contamination.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Giving out confidential information to anyone other than those permitted in the legislation is against the law.

Maintaining confidentiality encourages food handlers to report their illness quickly and assures them that the information will not be used for any purpose other than to protect food from contamination.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Summary

Thank you for taking the time to complete the Health and hygiene self-assessment.

A self-assessment summary has been generated from your responses to each question. From this page you can:

  • View resources for more information about this topic
  • Download a summary of your self-assessment
  • Email a summary of your self-assessment
  • Start another next self-assessment topic

Contact your local council if you would like further information or resources for your food business.

components.content:
Topics to complete

There are still other topics you may wish to complete your self-assessment for.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Clean and sanitise

One of most effective ways for making sure your food stays safe is to keep a clean premise. This will help to prevent contamination in the food you prepare and sell.

You need a cleaning system for every area of your business. This includes your premise, equipment and vehicles used to transport food.

Staff responsible for cleaning and sanitising should understand:

  • how to use different chemicals
  • where to clean
  • how to take apart equipment such as food processors to clean and sanitise them correctly.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • Do you have a cleaning roster?
  • Is every area of your food business included in your cleaning roster?
  • Do you or your staff know how to clean and sanitise correctly?
  • Do you have the right chemicals to sanitise correctly?

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Terms of use

Please read and accept the terms of use before using the Know Your Food Business self-assessment tool

  • Terms and Conditions
  • Privacy statement
  • Disclaimer
  • Copyright

Queensland Health respects your right to privacy in using Know Your Food Business self-assessment tool. Any information you give will be handled by Queensland Health in accordance with the Information Privacy Act 2009.

For information about how Queensland Health protects your personal information, or to learn about your right to access your personal information, please see out website at www.health.qld.gov.au

Please note that our terms of use may change over time. Your use of this website is your agreement to our terms and conditions.

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Clean and sanitise

components.legend: Is your premise kept clean at all times?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • no visible dirt, grease and other matter
  • no build-up of garbage or recycling
  • crumbs and other food waste are not caught in corners or under benches
  • grease filters are cleaned regularly
  • no mould
  • no spider webs

components.label: Is your premise kept clean at all times?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Keeping your premise and equipment clean and sanitised is an easy way to make sure your food is safe.

You may find it helpful to develop a cleaning schedule. A draft procedure including example records is provided at the end of this topic.

components.legend: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • benches, shelves, cupboards
  • sinks, handwash basins
  • fridges, cool rooms, bain marie units
  • parts of vehicles used to transport food. Note: vehicles includes shopping trolleys and baskets

components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must clean and sanitise all equipment to prevent food contamination.

You may find it helpful to develop a cleaning roster. You can download a draft procedure, including example records at the end of this topic.

components.legend: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
components.label: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • utensils
  • chopping boards
  • work benches
  • equipment

components.label: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces:

  • before you start processing food
  • in between different jobs.

It is also important to regularly clean and sanitise throughout the day, even if used for the same food. This will help to stop germs multiplying during the day.

For further information, read the fact sheet in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Are eating and drinking utensils cleaned and sanitised before each use?
components.label: Are eating and drinking utensils cleaned and sanitised before each use?
Are eating and drinking utensils cleaned and sanitised before each use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must to clean and sanitise eating and drinking utensils after every customer use.

Customers may re-use their own utensils (e.g.: at a buffet). However, when a customer returns the utensils to you, you must clean and sanitise the utensils before they can be used again.

components.legend: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
components.label: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint"> Cleaning removes dirt. Sanitising kills germs. They are usually separate steps and must done with food grade chemicals.
</small>

components.label: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cleaning and sanitising play a very important role in making sure you produce safe food. Sanitising can be done two ways, with heat or by using a food grade sanitiser.

There are 6 easy steps to clean and sanitise dishes that are hand washed

  1. Pre-clean: scrape or wipe away food scraps and other matter and rinse with water.
  2. Wash use hot water and detergent to take off any grease and dirt. Soak if needed.
  3. Rinse: rinse off detergent and any loosened residue.
  4. Sanitise: use a sanitiser to destroy any remaining bacteria.
  5. Final Rinse: wash off sanitiser if necessary (refer to manufacturers instructions).
  6. Dry: allow to drip dry or dry using single use towels.

Dishes can be sanitised using a commercial dishwasher where the temperature reaches greater than 80 degrees.

For further information, read the fact sheet in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you have a cleaning system?
components.label: Do you have a cleaning system?
HTML
components.content:
A cleaning system may include:
  • what needs to be cleaned
  • how often cleaning is to be done
  • how something is to be cleaned
  • a roster of who will do the cleaning
  • a record of when cleaning is done
  • details on what chemicals are used.

components.label: Do you have a cleaning system?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You can prevent food contamination by keeping your premise and equipment clean.

We recommend that you have a cleaning system in place with:

  • processes to describe what needs to be cleaned, how often it is cleaned, and how it is cleaned
  • a cleaning roster for staff
  • a record of when cleaning is done
  • details on what chemicals are required.

For more information, see the cleaning and sanitising guide with an example cleaning record at the end of this topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Summary

Thank you for taking the time to complete the Clean and sanitise self-assessment.

A self-assessment summary has been generated from your responses to each question. From this page you can:

Contact your local council if you would like further information or resources for your food business.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Label Buster

Label Buster is a step-by-step guide to help you identify the information you need to create a food label that meets Australian requirements. At the end of Label Buster, you will generate:

  • a product sheet you can give to a printer to design a label for you
  • an example of what your food label should look like.

The Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (the Food Standards Code) sets the standards for food labelling in Australia. Significant penalties apply in Queensland under the Food Act 2006 (the Act), for non-compliance with the Food Standards Code.

Did you know

Labels must have the same information whether you sell your product once at a market stall, or regularly to a supermarket.

Who can use Label Buster?

Label Buster is designed for small to medium food businesses. If your food has complex labelling requirements, such as infant formula, sports supplements or alcohol, the tool does not provide all the information you need, and you are recommended to seek professional legal advice from a food labelling consultant.

Before you start

To use Label Buster, you will need:

Up to 1 hour - if you are familiar with food labelling requirements.

Up to 2 hours - if you have never made a food label before.

You will need information about your food, such as:

  • ingredients
  • use-by or best-before dates
  • any storage conditions or directions for use

The questions marked with a * must be completed. Other questions are optional.

Did you know

Label Buster will provide you with food labelling information to help you to comply with the Food Standards Code. After you finish Label Buster, you will need to include other mandatory requirements for a Nutrition Information Panel , weights and measures , and Country of origin labelling. Health Star Rating is a voluntary scheme you can choose to add to your food.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Terms of use

Please read and accept the terms of use before using Label Buster

  • Terms and conditions
  • Privacy statement
  • Disclaimer
  • Copyright

Warning

This tool does not meet all your legislative requirements, only those relating to the Food Standards Code. You will need to include other requirements on your food label, such as country of origin labelling.

It is your responsibility to ensure all the information on your food label is true and correct.

Queensland Health respects your right to privacy in using Label Buster. Any information you give will be handled by Queensland Health in accordance with the Information Privacy Act 2009.

No personal information is stored when you use Label Buster. For information about how Queensland Health protects your personal information, or to learn about your right to access your personal information, please see our website at www.health.qld.gov.au

Please note that our terms of use may change over time.

Label Buster is current as of June 2020 and shows information up to and including amendment number 192 of the Food Standards Code. It is recommended that you refer to the most current version of the Food Standards Code for full details and note any changes.

Your use of this website is your agreement to our terms and conditions.

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Label Buster
HTML
components.content:
About food labels

Select on the food label sections below to learn about labels.

|

Food labels must show the name of the food to help identify the food.

The name and description of the food must reflect its true nature. For example, strawberry yoghurt must contain strawberries. If the yoghurt contained strawberry flavouring rather than real fruit, then the name would need to indicate that it is strawberry-flavoured yoghurt.

If the name of the food does not reflect its true nature, then you must include a description of the true nature on the label. For example, Lukes Hots Sauce (red chilli pepper sauce).

To help customers identify where food has come from or to use for a food recall when food is unsafe, a food label must include the following business details:

  • name of the business supplying the food
  • business address in Australia or New Zealand, or a description of the location, of the premises where the business is being operated. A postal address cannot be used.

The National Measurement Institute is responsible for making sure food is measured and weighed correctly, and that the food is labelled with the correct weight and unit.

For example, food labelled as being 500g should weigh 500g and use the metric system of grams (g), kilograms (kg), millilitres (mL), litres (L), etc.

Visit the NMI website for more information on how to comply with the laws around weights and other measures.

Food packaged with a shelf life of 2 years or less must show a date mark.

Foods that should be eaten before a certain date for health and safety reasons must be labelled with a use-by date. Otherwise, a best-before date is required if the food has a shelf life of less than 2 years. Although it may be safe to eat the food after the best-before date, the food may have lost quality or some nutritional value.

Bread with a shelf-life of less than 7 days, can use a baked-for date or baked-on date instead of a best-before date.

The lot identification means a number or other information that identifies where the food was made and the batch it was part of. Often the date mark, name and address of the manufacturer meets this requirement.

Storage conditions
To keep food until its best-before or use-by date include storage conditions on your label.

Directions for use
A food label must have directions on how to use or prepare the food if needed for health and safety reasons.

A food label must contain a list of ingredients. The Food Standards Code has rules that describe how each ingredient must be listed, what it is called, and how it is formatted.

To help consumers avoid foods that are not safe for them to eat due to health conditions they may have, the Food Standards Code lists mandatory advisory statements, warning statements and allergen declarations that must be shown on a food label depending on the type of food and its ingredients.

The nutrition information panel (NIP) shows the number of servings in the package and the average amounts in a serving of food and per 100 grams (or 100 millilitres) of food for:

  • energy (in kilojoules)
  • protein
  • fat (including saturated fat)
  • carbohydrates (including sugars)
  • sodium

If a nutrition, health or related claim is made, the NIP must also show the amount of nutrient or substance. For example: the amount of calcium must be shown in the nutrition information panel if a claim about calcium is made.

There are strict requirements about claims that can be made and how they should be written on a label.

Nutrition content claims are claims about the content of certain nutrients or substances in a food. For example, contains calcium.

Health claims refer to a relationship between food and health. For example, calcium for bone and teeth.

Seek professional advice

Please note, that about your food has other requirements such as additional information in your nutritional information panel and requirements under Australian Consumer Law.

You can only continue using Label Buster if you choose not to make a claim about your product.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Food name and description

The purpose of a is to correctly describe what the food is. It cannot mislead the customer.

The Food Standards Code has rules on what you can name your food.

components.legend: Does your food name, or label, highlight an ingredient?
components.label: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (characterising ingredients)?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • Strawberries in strawberry yoghurt
  • Wholegrain in wholegrain bread
  • A picture of a honey pot on a muesli bar

components.label: Does your food name, or label, highlight an ingredient?
HTML
components.content:
Characterising ingredients

Ingredients which are mentioned in the food name are called The Food Standards Code requires the amount of characterising ingredients to be shown in the ingredients list.

components.legend: Is your food one of the following:
components.label: Does your food name, or label, highlight an ingredient?

components.content: • (For example: salami, chorizo, pepperoni)

components.label: Is your food one of the following:

components.content:
Prescribed names

These foods have names that must be used ().

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Food with extra requirements

Some foods have extra requirements. Use the to find out what they are.

For example: Ice cream must be made from milk to call it ice cream. Jam must be made from fruit to call it jam.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Business details

Food labels must include the business details (name and address) of the supplier on the label. A supplier is a business which packs, manufactures, sells or imports food. Business details help consumers, other businesses and government agencies know who to contact in the event of a complaint or food recall.

components.label:
Business name
This is the name of the food business that is the supplier, manufacturer, packer, vendor or importer of the food.

Business address
A business address is the street address, or a description of the location, of the premises, where the business is operating in Australia. A post office box or similar is not allowed.

Date marks

Foods that should be eaten before a certain date for health and safety reasons must be labelled with a use-by date. Other food that should be eaten in 2 years must have a best-before date.

Does your food need to be eaten before a certain date because of health and safety? *
For example:

components.content:
Use-by date

These foods must be labelled with a because they may become unsafe to eat after the use-by date has passed. A food may look, smell and taste ok but be unsafe to eat.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Best-before date

A is required for all foods with a shelf life of 2 years or less that do not need a The best-before date is the date up to which the food remains with good appearance, smell and taste, and keeps any qualities for which a claim has been made.

components.label: What type of date mark do you need for your food? *

values.label: <button data-accordion-item="what-date-mark" class="accordion-btn">       Do not need a date mark     </button>

components.label: HTML
components.content:
What is the date for the food?
The date will usually be in the of:
  • dd/mm/yyyy (e.g.: 15/3/2020) for food with a shelf life of 3 months or less, or
  • mmm/yyyy (e.g.: Apr 2021) for food with a shelf life of more than 3 months.

Leave this question blank if the food is not packaged or does not need a date mark.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Lot identification
helps identify food. If using your date mark, leave blank or enter a batch number below.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Storage and use

Storage conditions describe how to keep food until its best-before or use-by date.

Directions for use are instructions for how to prepare the food so that it is ready to eat.

Storage conditions

Select the for your food.
If your food has specific storage conditions to make sure it will keep until the best-before or use-by date, then you must include these on the label. Examples of some storage conditions have been included. You may select none, or one or more of these, depending on your requirements.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Ingredients

A food label must contain a list of ingredients that have been used to make the food. This is also known as the statement of ingredients.

components.legend: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (<button data-accordion-item="char-ingredient" class="accordion-btn">characterising ingredients</button> )?
components.label: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (characterising ingredients)?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint">For example: strawberries in strawberry jam, meat in a meat pie. </small>

components.label: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (<button data-accordion-item="char-ingredient" class="accordion-btn">characterising ingredients</button> )?
HTML
components.content:
Characterising ingredients

Food labels must show the percentage of the characterising ingredients in the food. The Food Standards Code provides details on how should be calculated and shown.

For example: The ingredient list would show the strawberries in strawberry jam as: Strawberries (23%).

components.legend: Do you use any <button data-accordion-item="comp-ingredient" class="accordion-btn"> compound ingredients </button>  to make your food?
components.label: Do you use any compound ingredients to make your food?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> A compound ingredient is any ingredient that is made from two or more ingredients. For example: chocolate chips in a muffin, tomato paste on a pizza. </small>

components.label: Do you use any compound ingredients to make your food?
HTML
components.content:
Compound ingredients

If a food contains that contribute 5% or more to the final food, then all the ingredients and additives in that compound ingredient must be declared. If a food contains a compound ingredient that contributes less than 5% to the final food, then only allergens and food additives require listing.

For example: The ingredient list would show the dark chocolate chips in a muffin as: dark chocolate chips [sugar, cocoa mass, cocoa butter, emulsifier (soy lecithin), natural vanilla flavour].

components.legend: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an     <button data-accordion-item="alt-ingredient" class="accordion-btn"> alternative ingredient  </button> to make your food?
components.label: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an alternative ingredient to make your food?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> This includes a food ingredient or additive that is replaced with another food or additive that serves the same function. For example: sultanas or raisins in a protein ball. </small>

components.label: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an alternative ingredient to make your food?
HTML
components.content:
Alternative ingredients

, including food additives, must be declared.

For example: The ingredient list would show: sultanas or raisins.

components.legend: Do you want to list an ingredient with a <button data-accordion-item="generic-name" class="accordion-btn"> generic name</button>?
components.label: Field Set
HTML
components.content:
Generic names may be used to describe the ingredient.

Cheese, cocoa butter, crystallised fruit, fruit, gum bases, herbs, meat, milk protein, poultry meat, spices and vegetables can be used as a generic name without any conditions.

, , , , , , , and have other requirements.

For example: Apple, pear and peach listed as fruit in a fruit pie.

components.label: Do you want to list an ingredient with a generic name?
HTML
components.content:
Generic names

are specified in the Food Standards Code.

For example: The ingredient list could show the ingredients apple, pear and peach as either:

  • Fruit, or
  • Fruit (apple, pear, peach)

components.legend: Does your food contain any         <button data-accordion-item="food-additive" class="accordion-btn">food additives </button>?
components.label: Does your food contain any food additives?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> For example: Food colours, flavours, preservatives, sweeteners, thickeners, etc. </small>

components.label: Does your food contain any food additives?
HTML
components.content:
Food additives

The substance (including a vitamin or mineral) used as a food additive must be declared.

The Food Standards Code specifies how to list in the ingredient list. This includes a list of class names and codes to use for specific food additives.

For example: The ingredient list would show the yellow food colouring tartrazine as either:

  • Colour (tartrazine), or
  • Colour (102)

components.legend: Does your food contain any         <button data-accordion-item="exempt-ingredient" class="accordion-btn">exempt ingredients </button> that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
components.label: Does your food contain any exempt ingredients that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
HTML
components.content:
For example:

  • A substance or food that is used as a processing aid.
  • An ingredient of a flavouring substance.
  • An ingredient such as water or alcohol, that is completely removed during the manufacture of the food.
  • Added water that forms part of broth, brine or syrup.

components.label: Does your food contain any exempt ingredients that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
HTML
components.content:
Exempt ingredients

do not need to be included in the ingredient list.

components.content: Enter ingredients in

components.label: Enter each ingredient that is used to make your food in descending order of ingoing weight.

To change the order of your ingredients:
  • Click the button
  • Drag and drop your ingredient

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Statements

Some foods or ingredients may be harmful to some people who are allergic or sensitive. These foods or ingredients must be written on the label no matter how small the amount and may also need a warning statement.

Allergen declarations

Select any food or ingredient in your food from the list below.

components.label:
Cereals containing gluten
For example, wheat, rye, barley, oats and spelt and their hybridised strains other than:
  • where these substances are present in beer and spirits; or
  • glucose syrups that are made from wheat starch and that:
    • have been subject to a refining process that has removed gluten protein content to the lowest level that is reasonably achievable; and
    • have a gluten protein content that does not exceed 20 mg/kg; or
  • alcohol distilled from wheat

Fish
Except for isinglass derived from swim bladders and used as a clarifying agent in beer or wine
Milk</br><small class="hint">Other than alcohol distilled from whey </small>

Soybeans
Other than:
  • soybean oil that has been degummed, neutralised, bleached and deodorised
  • soybean derivatives that are a tocopherol or a phytosterol
Sulphites added in concentrations of 10mg/kg or more

Tree nuts
Other than coconut from the fruit of the palm Cocos nucifera.
HTML
components.content:
The allergens should be shown on the food label as:

Contains: {{_.reduce(_.filter(_.toPairs(data.allergyDeclarations), function([key, val]) { return val }), function(acc, [key, val], index) { if (index === _.filter(_.toPairs(data.allergyDeclarations), function([key, val]) { return val }).length - 1) return acc + ` ${val}.`; return acc + ` ${val}, `; }, '') }}

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Your label information

Congratulations! You have completed all the steps in Label Buster.

Using your responses to each question, Label Buster has generated a product sheet and an example food label.

Label Buster is a brief guide to help you understand your labelling requirements. You may choose to get advice from a labelling consultant to make sure that your label complies with the Food Standards Code.

On this page, you will find:

  • Product sheet
  • Example food label
  • Legibility requirements
  • Exemptions
  • Download or email your summary
  • Need to update your label?

Product Sheet

You can take this information to a printer or graphic designer to create a label or use your own tools/templates. When creating your food label, you must ensure you meet the legibility requirements , such as minimum type size.

Claims

Making voluntary claims about your food is very complex and you are recommended to seek professional advice.
Please note, that making a claim on your food has other requirements not addressed in Label Buster such as additional sections in your nutritional information panel and requirements under Australian Consumer Law.

Country of origin Information on how to calculate and display mandatory country of origin can be found on the Australian Competition and Consumer Commissionwebsite.
Health star rating Information on how to calculate and display a voluntary health star rating can be found at the health star rating system website.

Legibility requirements

All required words, statements, expressions or designs provided on a food label must be in English, be legible, and be prominent so as to contrast distinctly with the background of the label.

Information in other languages is permitted, provided it does not negate or contradict the English information.

No specific print type or size is defined for general labelling requirements, however:

  • warning statements must be in a type size of at least 3mm (or 1.5mm on small packages)
  • a print size is prescribed in the Food Standards Code for some foods where a required statement must be shown (e.g. infant formula).

Exemptions

All of the food label information needs to be included on your food label, except for:

  • Food sold in small packages
  • Food with one ingredient

There are extra requirements for:

  • Food sold from a vending machine
  • Food sold in a hamper

Your label information summary

Download your label information summary. This summary includes your product sheet and an example of what your label could look like.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Label Buster

Label Buster is a step-by-step guide to help you identify information you need to create a food label that meets Australian requirements. At the end of Label Buster, you will generate:

  • a product sheet you can give to a printer to design a label for you
  • an example of what your food label should look like.

The Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (the Food Standards Code) sets the standards for food labelling in Australia. Significant penalties apply in Queensland under the Food Act 2006 (the Act), for non-compliance with the Food Standards Code.

Did you know

Labels must have the same information whether you sell your product once at a market stall, or regularly to a supermarket.

Who can use Label Buster?

Label Buster is designed for small to medium food businesses. If your food has complex labelling requirements, such as infant formula, sports supplements or alcohol, the tool does not provide all the information you need, and you are recommended to seek professional legal advice from a food labelling consultant.

Before you start

To use Label Buster, you will need:

Up to 1 hour - if you are familiar with food labelling requirements.

Up to 2 hours - if you have never made a food label before.

You will need information about your food, such as:

  • ingredients
  • use-by or best-before dates
  • any storage conditions or directions for use

The questions marked with a * must be completed. Other questions are optional.

Did you know

Label Buster will provide you with food labelling information to help you to comply with the Food Standards Code. After you finish Label Buster, you will need to include other mandatory requirements for a Nutrition Information Panel , weights and measures , and Country of origin labelling. Health Star Rating is a voluntary scheme you can choose to add to your food.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Terms of use

Please read and accept the terms of use before using Label Buster

  • Terms and conditions
  • Privacy statement
  • Disclaimer
  • Copyright

Warning

This tool does not meet all your legislative requirements, only those relating to the Food Standards Code. You will need to include other requirements on your food label, such as country of origin labelling.

It is your responsibility to ensure all the information on your food label is true and correct.

Queensland Health respects your right to privacy in using Label Buster. Any information you give will be handled by Queensland Health in accordance with the Information Privacy Act 2009.

No personal information is stored when you use Label Buster. For information about how Queensland Health protects your personal information, or to learn about your right to access your personal information, please see out website at www.health.qld.gov.au

Please note that our terms of use may change over time.

Label Buster is current as of June 2020 and shows information up to and including amendment number 192 of the Food Standards Code. It is recommended that you refer to the most current version of the Food Standards Code for full details and note any changes.

Your use of this website is your agreement to our terms and conditions.

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Label Buster
HTML
components.content:
About food labels

Select on the food label sections below to learn about labels.

|

Food labels must show the name of the food to help identify the food.

The name and description of the food must reflect its true nature. For example, strawberry yoghurt must contain strawberries. If the yoghurt contained strawberry flavouring rather than real fruit, then the name would need to indicate that it is strawberry-flavoured yoghurt.

If the name of the food does not reflect its true nature, then you must include a description of the true nature on the label. For example, Lukes Hots Sauce (red chilli pepper sauce).

To help customers identify where food has come from or to use for a food recall when food is unsafe, a food label must include the following business details:

  • name of the business supplying the food
  • business address in Australia or New Zealand, or a description of the location, of the premises where the business is being operated. A postal address cannot be used.

The National Measurement Institute is responsible for making sure food is measured and weighed correctly, and that the food is labelled with the correct weight and unit.

For example, food labelled as being 500g should weigh 500g and use the metric system of grams (g), kilograms (kg), millilitres (mL), litres (L), etc.

Visit the NMI website for more information on how to comply with the laws around weights and other measures.

Food packaged with a shelf life of 2 years or less must show a date mark.

Foods that should be eaten before a certain date for health and safety reasons must be labelled with a use-by date. Otherwise, a best-before date is required if the food has a shelf life of less than 2 years. Although it may be safe to eat the food after the best-before date, the food may have lost quality or some nutritional value.

Bread with a shelf-life of less than 7 days, can use a baked-for date or baked-on date instead of a best-before date.

The lot identification means a number or other information that identifies where the food was made and the batch it was part of. Often the date mark, name and address of the manufacturer meets this requirement.

Storage conditions
To keep food until its best-before or use-by date include storage conditions on your label.

Directions for use
A food label must have directions on how to use or prepare the food if needed for health and safety reasons.

A food label must contain a list of ingredients. The Food Standards Code has rules that describe how each ingredient must be listed, what it is called, and how it is formatted.

To help consumers avoid foods that are not safe for them to eat due to health conditions they may have, the Food Standards Code lists mandatory advisory statements, warning statements and allergen declarations that must be shown on a food label depending on the type of food and its ingredients.

The nutrition information panel (NIP) shows the number of servings in the package and the average amounts in a serving of food and per 100 grams (or 100 millilitres) of food for:

  • energy (in kilojoules)
  • protein
  • fat (including saturated fat)
  • carbohydrates (including sugars)
  • sodium

If a nutrition, health or related claim is made, the NIP must also show the amount of nutrient or substance. For example: the amount of calcium must be shown in the nutrition information panel if a claim about calcium is made.

There are strict requirements about claims that can be made and how they should be written on a label.

Nutrition content claims are claims about the content of certain nutrients or substances in a food. For example, contains calcium.

Health claims refer to a relationship between food and health. For example, calcium for bone and teeth.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Limitations of Label Buster

Foods with complex labelling requirements are excluded from Label Buster. The following questions will help you to work out if you can use Label Buster for your food.

components.label:
Is your food:*

  • an
  • a ,
  • an
  • a
  • a drink base (solid or liquid) that is used to make any of the drinks above?
For example: Beer, wine, spirits, energy drink or breakfast drink. Select no if your food contains alcohol as an ingredient but is not a drink (e.g.: brandy custard, rum balls).
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Thank you for your interest in Label Buster. Unfortunately, Label buster does not provide labelling information for these drinks. We recommend you seek professional advice from a food labelling consultant to prepare your food label.

components.label:
Is your food a special purpose food? Special purpose foods include:
  • Infant formula products
  • Foods for infants
  • Formulated meal replacements and formulated supplementary foods
  • Formulated supplementary sports foods
  • Food for special medical purposes
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Thank you for your interest in Label Buster. Unfortunately, Label Buster does not provide labelling information for special purposefoods. We recommend you seek professional advice from a food labelling consultant to prepare your food label.

components.label: Is your food a <button class="accordion-btn" data-accordion-item="novel-food">novel food</button> or does it contain an ingredient that is a novel food?</br><small class="hint">A novel food is a food or component that does not have a history of human consumption in Australia or New Zealand. This includes food that is typically not considered food, or a food made from processes not previously applied to food.</small>
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Thank you for your interest in Label Buster. Unfortunately, Label Buster does not provide labelling information for novel foods.

Novel foods require pre-market clearance before the food can be sold. We recommend you seek professional advice from a food labelling consultant to prepare your food label.

components.label: Does your food contain ingredients that are produced from gene technology, or is your food a <button data-accordion-item="modified-food" class="accordion-btn">genetically modified food</button>
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Thank you for your interest in Label Buster. Unfortunately, Label Buster does not provide labelling information for genetically modified foods.

Genetically modified food requires pre-market clearance before the food can be sold. We recommend you seek professional advice from a food labelling consultant to prepare your food label.

components.label: Is your food an <button class="accordion-btn" data-accordion-item="irradiated-food">irradiated food</button><small class="hint">Irradiation of food is prohibited unless specifically permitted by the Food Standards Code and must comply with the specified conditions, using only a permitted source of radiation.</small>
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Thank you for your interest in Label Buster. Unfortunately, Label Buster does not provide labelling information for genetically modified foods.

Genetically modified food requires pre-market clearance before the food can be sold. We recommend you seek professional advice from a food labelling consultant to prepare your food label.

components.label:
Do you make a about your food?
Claims are voluntary statements made on a food label and in advertising about a link between your food and health. For example, Gluten free, good source of calcium, organic, cage free.
HTML
components.content:
Seek professional advice

Making voluntary about your food is very complex and you are recommended to seek professional advice.

Please note, that about your food has other requirements such as additional information in your nutritional information panel and requirements under Australian Consumer Law.

You can only continue using Label Buster if you choose not to make a claim about your product.

components.label: HTML
components.content: The purpose of a food name and description is to correctly describe what the food is, it cannot mislead the customer. The Food standards Code has rules on what you can name your food.

components.label:
Does your food name, or label, highlight an ingredient?
For example:
  • Strawberries in strawberry yoghurt
  • Wholegrain in wholegrain bread
  • A picture of a cow on a soy milk

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Statements

Some foods or ingredients may be harmful to some people who are allergic or sensitive. These foods or ingredients must be written on the label no matter how small the amount and may also need a warning statement.

Allergen declarations

Select any food or ingredient in your food from the allergen declaration list below.

components.label:
Cereals containing gluten
For example, wheat, rye, barley, oats and spelt and their hybridised strains other than:
  • where these substances are present in beer and spirits; or
  • glucose syrups that are made from wheat starch and that:
    • have been subject to a refining process that has removed gluten protein content to the lowest level that is reasonably achievable; and
    • have a gluten protein content that does not exceed 20 mg/kg; or
  • alcohol distilled from wheat

Fish
Except for isinglass derived from swim bladders and used as a clarifying agent in beer or wine

Milk
Other than alcohol distilled from whey

Soybeans
Other than:
  • soybean oil that has been degummed, neutralised, bleached and deodorised
  • soybean derivatives that are a tocopherol or a phytosterol
Sulphites added in concentrations of 10mg/kg or more

Tree nuts
Other than coconut from the fruit of the palm Cocos nucifera.
HTML

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Your label information

Congratulations! You have completed all the steps in Label Buster.

Using your responses to each question, Label Buster has generated a product sheet and an example food label.

Label Buster is a brief guide to help you understand your labelling requirements. You may choose to get advice from a labelling consultant to make sure that your label complies with the Food Standards Code.

On this page, you will find:

  • Product sheet
  • Example food label
  • Legibility requirements
  • Exemptions
  • Download or email your summary
  • Need to update your label?

Product Sheet

You can take this information to a printer or graphic designer to create a label or use your own tools/templates. When creating your food label, you must ensure you meet the legibility requirements , such as minimum type size.

Food name and description Strawberry yoghurt crunch A healthy breakfast yoghurt with banana granola and dark chocolate.
Business details Label Buster Foods, 123 Rocky Road, FOODTOWN QLD 4444
Ingredients Ingredients: Yoghurt (55%) [skim milk, cream, live yoghurt cultures, intense sweetener (962)], strawberries (21%), rolled oats (gluten), banana (4.5%), dark chocolate (5%)[sugar, milk solids, cocoa butter, cocoa mass, emulsifiers (322 (soy), 476), flavours], honey, dried figs, pecans, almonds, sunflower seeds, vanilla bean extract [thickener (413)], cinnamon
Weight For information on how to comply with weights and measures laws visit the National Measurement Institute website.
Nutrition information panel A Nutrition Information Panel must be added to your food label. The Food Standards Australia New Zealand nutrition panel calculator can help you prepare your nutrition information panel.
Statements and declarations

Contains: gluten, milk, tree nuts, soy. This food contains phenylalanine.
Note: Warning statements must be a minimum size of type of 3 mm. In the case of small packages, a minimum size of type of 1.5 mm is required.
Date marks Best Before:05 /04/2021
Lot identification Batch 42
Storage conditions and directions for use

Storage conditions: Keep refrigerated at 1C to 5C. Store in an upright position.
Directions for use: Consume within 2 days of opening.

Claims

Making voluntary claims about your food is very complex and you are recommended to seek professional advice.
Please note, that making a claim on your food has other requirements not addressed in Label Buster such as additional sections in your nutritional information panel and requirements under Australian Consumer Law.

Country of origin Information on how to calculate and display mandatory country of origin can be found on the Australian Competition and Consumer Commissionwebsite.
Health star rating Information on how to calculate and display a voluntary health star rating can be found at the health star rating system website.

Example of food label

Below is an example of what your label could look like, using the information you provided in Label Buster. Label components can be placed anywhere on the label you create. They do not need to be in the specific layout shown here. They may be displayed in any order or arrangement

Legibility requirements

All required words, statements, expressions or designs provided on a food label must be in English, be legible, and be prominent so as to contrast distinctly with the background of the label.

Information in other languages is permitted, provided it does not negate or contradict the English information.

No specific print type or size is defined for general labelling requirements, however:

  • warning statements must be in a type size of at least 3mm (or 1.5mm on small packages)
  • a print size is prescribed in the Food Standards Code for some foods where a required statement must be shown (e.g. infant formula).

Exemptions

All of the food label information needs to be included on your food label, except for:

  • Food sold in small packages
  • Food with one ingredient

There are extra requirements for:

  • Food sold from a vending machine
  • Food sold in a hamper

Your label information summary

Download your label information summary. This summary includes your product sheet and an example of what your label could look like.

If you prefer, we can send you your self-assessment summary by providing an email address below.

Email

Depending on your email provider, personal information may be transferred outside of Australia. By providing your email address, you voluntarily agree to this transfer.


Need to update your food label?

If you would like to update details in your food label, such as different flavours or ingredients, you can go back and update your answers by clicking on the relevant step. You can then regenerate your label with these new details.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Know your food business

The Know Your Food Business self-assessment tool is provided for small to medium food businesses. Thistoolcan help you to assess whether you meet the requirements of theFood Act 2006and theAustralia New Zealand Food Standards Code.

There are11 assessment topics to complete.You will be askedquestions about a range of food safety topics.

You will be offered resourcesthat link you to more information about each topic. At the end of each self-assessment topic, you can download or email the list of resources that you have selected.

Topics to Complete

Each topic takes about 5 to 10 minutes to complete

People

Process

Premises and equipment

Completed topics

You can restart a completed topic by clicking on the topic link below.
