Download factsheet (PDF, 106 KB)

SIC protocol

A guide to help food businesses identify and respond to incidents of suspected intentional contamination of food

Download guide (PDF, 1.2 MB)

Food Recalls

Key information about what a food business should do with food that has been recalled for health and safety reasons.

Download factsheet (PDF, 146 KB)

Food Industry Recall Protocol

Information on recalling food in Australia and writing a food recall plan

Go to website

Recall of exported food

The Department of Agriculture and Water Resources is responsible for advising importing country authorities of instances where exported Australian food poses a food safety risk and has been subject to a recall, including trade recalls.

Go to website

Current food recalls subscription service

A free subscription to all the latest food recalls

Go to website

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Maintenance

Damaged parts and equipment are difficult to clean and may not work properly. This can cause food to become unsafe.

You should regularly check your premises and equipment to make sure that they are in good working order. This includes any vehicles used to transport food.

Having equipment serviced regularly and professionally cleaned helps to maintain your premises and produce safe food.

components.legend: Is  your premise in a good state of repair and working order?
components.label: Is  your premise in a good state of repair and working order?
HTML
components.content:
For example: signs of poor maintenance include:
  • damage to doors and screens
  • loose or cracked tiles on the floors and walls
  • peeling paint and plaster on walls
  • leaking pipes or broken plumbing
  • damaged electrical outlets, lights or fans
  • holes in the ceiling, walls or doors

components.label: Is your premise in a good state of repair and working order?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food premise must be maintained to:

  • prevent contamination of food
  • prevent pests from coming into your food premise
  • clean and sanitise surfaces and equipment correctly
  • have a safe environment for staff and customers.

To improve food safety, consider the following actions:
  • Inspect your food premise to see what you need to repair or replace.
  • Use signage and inform staff of any items that are unsafe to use or could cause food safety issues.
  • Plan service or maintenance activities at a time that will not interfere with food preparation.
  • Create a maintenance schedule and checklist to regularly inspect your premise.

components.legend: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment in a good state of repair and working order?
components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment in a good state of repair and working order?
HTML
components.content:
For example: signs of poor maintenance include:
  • damaged benches, shelves, cupboards
  • broken taps in sinks and handwash basins
  • damaged or broken fridges or cool rooms and their seals
  • damaged ovens, microwaves, grills, fryers, rotisseries, bain-marie units etc
  • broken cooking utensils, food processing equipment or food containers
  • damaged knives, chopping boards, tongs, serving utensils
  • broken shopping trolleys or baskets
  • damaged parts of vehicles used to transport food

components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment in a good state of repair and working order?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Maintaining fittings, fixtures and equipment helps to:

  • prevent contamination of food
  • clean and sanitise surfaces and equipment correctly
  • have a safe environment for staff and customers.

components.legend: Do you have any chipped, cracked or broken plates and cups?
components.label: Do you have any chipped, cracked or broken plates and cups?
Do you have any chipped, cracked or broken plates and cups?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must not use any utensils or equipment that is chipped, cracked or broken. Germs can get into the damaged area. This may contaminate food and make your customers sick.

You should throw out any utensils and equipment that is damaged.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.legend: Do you regularly have equipment serviced and calibrated?
components.label: Do you regularly have equipment serviced and calibrated?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • fridges and cold rooms
  • dishwashers
  • thermometers
  • exhaust canopies

components.label: Do you regularly have equipment serviced and calibrated?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

To make sure all your equipment is working correctly, it is good practice to have them serviced and calibrated by a specialist.

components.legend: Do you regularly check that your thermometer is working correctly?
components.label: Do you regularly check that your thermometer is working correctly?
HTML
components.content:
You can check that your thermometer is working correctly by:
  • regular calibration
  • replacing the battery
  • fixing or replacing the thermometer if it breaks.

components.label: Do you regularly check that your thermometer is working correctly?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You need an accurate thermometer to get correct temperature readings.

You must regularly calibrate your thermometer to check that it is accurate to +/-1C.

See the example procedure at the end of the topic to find out how to calibrate a thermometer.

components.legend: Do you have equipment professionally cleaned or serviced when needed?
components.label: Do you have equipment professionally cleaned or serviced when needed?
HTML
components.content:
For example:

  • exhaust canopies
  • industry deep fryers
  • fridges and freezers
  • grease traps

components.label: Do you have equipment professionally cleaned or serviced when needed?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Specialist equipment should be regularly cleaned and serviced by a professional.

This will help you to:

  • Make sure that the equipment is working correctly to meet food safety requirements
  • Meet other requirements (e.g.: insurance, or where you need to show that your equipment meets Australian Standards).

components.legend: Do you undertake regular pest management?
components.label: Do you undertake regular pest management?
Do you undertake regular pest management?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Remember to check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs) between treatments. Call your technician if you need extra treatment.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may become contaminated.

Consider these actions:

  • Have regular pest control done and keep receipts for each time it is done.
  • Regularly check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs).
  • Seal any holes or gaps that may allow pest entry.

For tips on how to stop pests, see the Controlling Pests factsheet at the end of this topic.

components.legend: Do you have a cleaning system?
components.label: Do you have a cleaning system?
HTML
components.content:
A cleaning system may include:

  • what needs to be cleaned
  • how often cleaning is to be done
  • how something is to be cleaned
  • a roster of who will do the cleaning
  • a record of when cleaning is done
  • details on what chemicals are used

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You can prevent food contamination by keeping your premise and equipment clean.

We recommend that you have a cleaning system in place with:

  • processes to describe what needs to be cleaned, how often it is cleaned, and how it is cleaned
  • a cleaning roster for staff
  • a record of when cleaning is done.

For more information, see the cleaning and sanitising guide with an example cleaning record at the end of this topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Resources

Below is a list of resources that you can view for more information about this topic.

Do Food Safely

A free online training program

Go to website

Cleaning and sanitising

Correct methods for cleaning and sanitising.

Download factsheet (DOCX, 295KB)
Download factsheet (PDF, 541 KB)
Download factsheet (PDF, 552 KB)
Download factsheet (PDF, 454 KB)

Animals in food premises

Information about the legislative requirements for animals in food business including definitions, tips for maintaining food safety standards and customer responsibilities.

Go to website

Calibrating thermometers

A procedure to calibrate a thermometer

Download procedure (DOC 122 KB)

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Notes

Use this section if you want to note any actions you've taken to improve your food safety.

The information contained in this document is confidential and for the sole use of the intended recipient(s). This confidentiality is not waived or lost, if you receive it and you are not the intended recipient(s), or if it is transmitted/received in error. Any unauthorised use, alteration, disclosure, distribution or review of this document is strictly prohibited. The information contained in this document, including any attachment sent with it, may be subject to a statutory duty of confidentiality if it relates to health service matters. If you are not the intended recipient(s), or if you have received this document in error, you are asked to immediately notify the sender by telephone in Australia 07 3328 9310 or email foodsafety@health.qld.gov.au. You should also delete this document, and any copies, from your computer system network and destroy any hard copies produced. If not an intended recipient of this document, you must not copy, distribute or take any action(s) that relies on it; any form of disclosure, modification, distribution and/or publication of this email is also prohibited. Although Queensland Health takes all reasonable steps to ensure this document does not contain malicious software, Queensland Health does not accept responsibility for the consequences if any person's computer inadvertently suffers any disruption to services, loss of information, harm or is infected with a virus, other malicious computer programme or code that may occur as a consequence of receiving this document. Unless stated otherwise, this document represents only the views of the sender and not the views of the Queensland Government.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Animals and pests

Animals and pests can:

  • contaminate surfaces, equipment and food
  • transfer bacteria from their bodies onto anything they touch.

Guide dogs and other assistance animals are allowed in any area used by customers. Assistance animals are defined by the Disability Discrimination Act 1922 (Cth).

components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
components.description: Ways to stop pests may include:

components.label: Business name
components.description: This is the name of the food business that is the supplier, manufacturer, packer, vendor or importer of the food.

components.label: Business Address
components.description: A business address is the street address, or a description of the location, of the premises, where the business is operating in Australia.  A post office box or similar is not allowed.

validate.customMessage: Nup, we need this filled out mate.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Your Label

Congratulations! You have completed all the steps in Label Buster.

Using your responses to each question, Label Buster has generated a product sheet and an example food label.

Label Buster is a brief guide to help you understand your labelling requirements. You may choose to get advice from a labelling consultant to make sure that your label complies with the Food Standards Code.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Product sheet

You can take this information to a printer or graphic designer to create a label or use your own tools/templates. When creating your food label, you must ensure you meet the legibility requirements, such as minimum type size.

Claims

Making voluntary claims about your food is very complex and you are recommended to seek professional advice.
Please note, that making a claim on your food has other requirements not addressed in Label Buster such as additional sections in your nutritional information panel and requirements under Australian Consumer Law.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Legibility requirements

All required words, statements, expressions or designs provided on a food label must be in English, be legible, and be prominent so as to contrast distinctly with the background of the label.

Information in other language is permitted, provided it does not negate or contradict the English information.

No specific print type or size is defined for general labelling requirements, however:

  • warning statements must be in a type size of at least 3mm (or 1.5mm on small packages)
  • A print size is prescribed in the Food Standards Code for some foods where a required statement must be shown (e.g. infant formula).

Exemptions

All of the food label information needs to be included on your food label, except for:

  • Food sold in small packages
  • Food with one ingredient

There are extra requirements for:

  • Food sold from a vending machine
  • Food sold in a hamper

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Date marks

Foods that should be eaten before a certain date for health and safety reasons must be labelled with a use-by date. Other food that should be eaten in 2 years must have a best-before date.

components.legend:
Does your food have a shelf life of more than 2 years? *
For example:
  • Apricot jam in a bottle that has been heat treated
  • Canned peaches
components.label: Field Set

Does your food have a shelf life of more than 2 years? *
For example:
  • Apricot jam in a bottle that has been heat treated
  • Canned peaches
HTML
components.content:
No date mark is required

No date marking information is required for a food with a shelf life of more than 2 years.

Manufacturers can choose to label this food with a packed-on date as a means of

components.legend: Is your food bread, with a shelf life of less than 7 days? *
components.label: Is your food bread, with a shelf life of less than 7 days? *
Is your food bread, with a shelf life of less than 7 days? *
HTML
components.content:
Best-before, baked-on or baked-for date

Bread with a shelf life of less than 7 days can be labelled using either a:

components.legend:
Does your food need to be eaten before a certain date because of health and safety? *
For example:
  • Food that may contain bacteria that will grow at fridge temperatures (e.g.: Listeria)
  • Perishable ready-to-eat food that will spoil (become mouldy, rancid or soured) before it becomes unsafe (e.g.: deli salads, prepared salads).
components.label:
Does your food need to be eaten before a certain date because of health and safety? *
For example:
  • Food that may contain bacteria that will grow at fridge temperatures (e.g.: Listeria)
  • Perishable ready-to-eat food that will spoil (become mouldy, rancid or soured) before it becomes unsafe (e.g.: deli salads, prepared salads).

Does your food need to be eaten before a certain date because of health and safety? *
For example:
  • Food that may contain bacteria that will grow at fridge temperatures (e.g.: Listeria)
  • Perishable ready-to-eat food that will spoil (become mouldy, rancid or soured) before it becomes unsafe (e.g.: deli salads, prepared salads).
HTML
components.content:
Use-by date

These foods must be labelled with a because they may become unsafe to eat after the use-by date has passed. A food may look, smell and taste ok but be unsafe to eat.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Best-before date

A is required for all foods with a shelf life of 2 years or less that do not need a The best-before date is the date up to which the food remains with good appearance, smell and taste, and keeps any qualities for which a claim has been made.

components.label: What type of date mark do you need for your food? *

values.label: <button data-accordion-item="what-date-mark" class="accordion-btn">       Do not need a date mark     </button>

components.label: HTML
components.content:
What is the date for the food?
The date will usually be in the of:
  • dd/mm/yyyy (e.g.: 15/3/2020) for food with a shelf life of 3 months or less, or
  • mmm/yyyy (e.g.: Apr 2021) for food with a shelf life of more than 3 months.

Leave this question blank if the food is not packaged or does not need a date mark.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Lot identification
helps identify food. If using your date mark, leave blank or enter a batch number below.

If you prefer, we can send you your self-assessment summary by providing an email address below.

Email

Depending on your email provider, personal information may be transferred outside of Australia. By providing your email address, you voluntarily agree to this transfer.
HTML
components.content:
Need to update your food label?

If you would like to update details in your food label, such as different flavours or ingredients, you can go back and update your answers by clicking on the relevant step. You can then regenerate your label with these new details.

components.label: HTML
components.content: The anchor target

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Skills and knowledge

Everyone working in a food business must have some skills and knowledge to handle food safely.

The level of food safety skills needed, will depend on the tasks done. For example, a chef that prepares food will need to know more about food safety than a shop assistant who restocks the refrigerator.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • the types of food you handle
  • the level of food processing you undertake
  • training of your food safety supervisor and food handlers

components.label: HTML
components.content:

HTML
components.content: Skills and knowledge

components.legend: Do you have a food safety supervisor?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> All licensed food businesses in Queensland must have a food safety supervisor. Select No if you do not need a food business licence. </small>

components.label: Do you have a food safety supervisor?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

A food safety supervisor is responsible for overseeing the day-to-day management of food safety in your business.

Read the food safety supervisor factsheet at the end of this topic to find out:

  • how to become a food safety supervisor
  • what it means to be a food safety supervisor

components.legend: Has your food safety supervisor completed training?
components.label: Has your food safety supervisor completed training?
Has your food safety supervisor completed training?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Food safety supervisors need to a high level of food safety knowledge so that they can guide your business.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

While training is not mandatory, we strongly recommend that your food safety supervisor completes training.

Food safety supervisors need to a high level of food safety knowledge so that they can guide your business.

Read the fact sheet at the end of the topic to find out more information about how to get training.

components.legend: Is food safety training provided to your staff?
components.label: Is food safety training provided to your staff?
HTML
components.content: For example, dogs, birds or other animals in the kitchen, storerooms and the loading dock.

components.label: Is food safety training provided to your staff?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

We recommend you maintain food safety training records for all food handlers at your food business. This includes:

  • internal training (e.g.: induction training)
  • on the job training
  • external training courses that provide a certificate of completion.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food safety training for staff will reduce the risk of food safety issues. Training could include:

  • induction training for new staff
  • on the job training
  • having staff complete free online courses
  • hiring a consultant to provide specialised training for your business

We recommend you maintain food safety training records for all food handlers at your food business. This includes:

  • internal training (e.g.: induction training)
  • on the job training
  • external training courses that provides a certificate of completion.

components.legend: Do staff know how and when to wash their hands?
components.label: Do staff know how and when to wash their hands?
Do staff know how and when to wash their hands?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Hand washing is a very important step in stopping cross contamination.

To help remind staff, hand washing posters are available to download at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Hand washing is a very important step in stopping cross contamination.

All food handlers must wash their hands:

  • All food handlers must wash their hands:
  • before handling food
  • after using the toilet, smoking, coughing, sneezing, eating, drinking or touching their face or head

Resources including posters on how and when to wash hands are included in the food safety resource kits at the end of the topic and should be shared with your staff.

components.legend: Do staff know how to clean and sanitise correctly?
components.label: Do staff know how to clean and sanitise correctly?
HTML
components.content: Cleaning removes dirt, sanitising kills germs. They are usually separate steps and must done with food grade sanitiser

components.label: Do staff know how to clean and sanitise correctly?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cleaning and sanitising play a very important role in making sure you produce safe food. Sanitising can be done two ways, with heat or by using a food grade sanitiser.

There are 6 easy steps to clean and sanitise dishes that are hand washed

  1. Pre-clean: scrape or wipe away food scraps and other matter and rinse with water.
  2. Wash: use hot water and detergent to take off any grease and dirt. Soak if needed.
  3. Rinse: rinse off detergent and any loosened residue.
  4. Sanitise: use a sanitiser to destroy any remaining bacteria.
  5. Final Rinse: wash off sanitiser if necessary (refer to manufacturers instructions).
  6. Dry: allow to drip dry or dry using single use towels.

Dishes can be sanitised using a commercial dishwasher where the temperature reaches greater than 80 degrees.

For further information, read the fact sheet in the resource list at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do staff know how to prevent cross contamination?
components.label: Do staff know how to prevent cross contamination?
HTML
components.content:
Cross contamination is when one item gets contaminated by another object which is already contaminated. For example:
  • touching food with unwashed hands
  • not cleaning and sanitising equipment between uses.

components.label: Do staff know how to prevent cross contamination?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Cross contamination is one of the leading causes of food poisoning.

You can reduce the risk of accidentally poisoning a customer when staff know:
  • how to handle food safely
  • ways to avoid contaminating surfaces
  • appropriate food storage methods

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Cross contamination is one of the leading causes of food poisoning.

You can reduce the risk of accidentally poisoning a customer when staff know:

  • how to handle food safely
  • ways to avoid contaminating surfaces
  • appropriate food storage methods

Fact sheets and posters on cross contamination can be found at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do staff know how to use your thermometer?
components.label: Do staff know how to use your thermometer?
Do staff know how to use your thermometer?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is mandatory to have a thermometer accurate to +/-1C. This allows staff to make sure your food is at the right temperatures during storage, display, transport and processing.

Like all equipment in your business, staff need to know how to use, clean and sanitise the thermometer correctly.

Further information on thermometers and how to calibrate them is included in the example procedure at the end of the topic.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Summary

Thank you for taking the time to complete the Skills and knowledge self-assessment.

A self-assessment summary has been generated from your responses to each question. From this page you can:

  • View resources for more information about this topic

components.content:
Topics to complete

There are still other topics you may wish to complete your self-assessment for.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Receive Food

Food businesses must only receive food that is safe and suitable. This means that food delivered to your business:

  • is protected from contamination
  • is labelled correctly
  • is at the correct temperature when it arrives.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • the type of food you receive
  • checks you do when you receive a delivery
  • where is food is delivered and stored until it is checked?
  • what time and day of the week that is food delivered?
  • who are your suppliers?

components.content:

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Receive Food

components.legend: Do you record the name and address of your suppliers?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
Do you record the name and address of your suppliers?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must be able to give the name and address for each supplier to a Council officer.

Knowing your suppliers details, helps:

  • if there is a food recall
  • if you have a food poisoning complaint.

components.legend: Do you check food on arrival for:
components.label: Are your fixtures, fittings and equipment clean?
HTML
components.content:
• correct temperature (<5C for chilled foods or frozen hard)
  • no signs of contamination
  • packaging is not broken
  • labelling including if the food is in the use-by or best-before date

components.label: Do you check food on arrival for:
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Checking all these things makes sure you only accept safe food into your business. It also helps to reduce stock loss as you can return or seek a credit from your supplier.

components.legend: Do you have a thermometer?
components.label: Do you clean and sanitise all food contact surfaces after each use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is mandatory to have a thermometer accurate to +/-1C. This allows staff to make sure your food is at the right temperature.

Accurate thermometers can be purchased from catering or kitchen supply stores.

Further information on thermometers and how to calibrate them in included in example procedure at the end of the topic

components.legend: Do you check eggs to see if they are:
components.label: Do you check eggs to see if they are:
HTML
components.content:
• clean
  • are not cracked
  • have a code stamped on them

components.label:
• clean
  • are not cracked
  • have a code stamped on them
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your eggs may not be safe. Eggs naturally carry bacteria, which makes them a high-risk food.

You should never use cracked or dirty eggs in the preparation of food.

The code stamped on the egg helps to identify which eggs to dispose of:

  • if there is a food recall
  • if you have a food poisoning complaint.

components.legend: Do you get food label information for the food that you receive?
components.label: Do your staff understand the difference between cleaning and sanitising?
HTML
components.content:
Food label information can include:

  • ingredients
  • allergens
  • country of origin labelling
  • name and address of supplier
  • date marks and lot identification
  • storage instructions

components.label: Do you get food label information for the food that you receive?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

Food labelling information will help you to:

  • Give information to your customers, so they can make informed choices based on their dietary needs (e.g.: for an allergy).
  • Manage your stock to use food within its expiry date.
  • Identify food that is part of a recall.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is important that you get food label information from your supplier for each item of food you use.

You can find label information:

  • on the food package
  • attached to the food package
  • in documentation provided by the supplier.

Food labelling information will help you to:

  • Give information to your customers, so they can make informed choices based on their dietary needs (e.g.: for an allergy).
  • Manage your stock to use food within its expiry date.
  • Identify food that is part of a food recall.

components.legend: Is food checked to be in the use-by or best-before date?
components.label: Is food checked to be in the use-by or best-before date?
Is food checked to be in the use-by or best-before date?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Food that is past its use-by date cannot be sold in Queensland for health and safety reasons. However, food that is past it's best-before date may be sold in Queensland.

It is important to check the date marking for all food received to make sure the food is safe to accept.

components.legend: Do you check that the delivery vehicle is clean?
components.label: Do you check that the delivery vehicle is clean?
Do you check that the delivery vehicle is clean?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

By rejecting food that has been contaminated, you are only receiving food that is safe.

We recommend you record the details of any food that you reject.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You may be receiving food that is not safe! Food that is contaminated or does not meet one of the checks above should be returned to the supplier or destroyed.

components.legend: Do you reject food that may be contaminated or does not pass one of the     checks above?
components.label: Do you reject food that may be contaminated or does not pass one of the     checks above?
HTML
components.content: Food that is contaminated, or has not been protected from contamination, is not safe and should be rejected. The food should either be returned to the supplier or destroyed with the supplier's consent.

components.label: Do you reject food that may be contaminated or does not pass one of the checks above?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You may be receiving food that is not safe! Food that is contaminated or does not meet one of the checks above should be returned to the supplier or destroyed.

components.legend: Do you keep a record of checks or food rejected?
components.label: Do you keep a record of checks or food rejected?
HTML
components.content: For example: a note on an invoice

components.label: Do you keep a record of checks or food rejected?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

It is helpful to keep some form of record of when food is not accepted. This helps when investigating food poisoning complaints to show you are only accepting safe food.

components.content:
Summary

Thank you for taking the time to complete the Receive food self-assessment.

A self-assessment summary has been generated from your responses to each question. From this page you can:

  • View resources for more information about this topic
  • Download a summary of your self-assessment
  • Email a summary of your self-assessment
  • Start another next self-assessment topic

Contact your local council if you would like further information or resources for your food business.

components.content:
Topics to complete

There are still other topics you may wish to complete your self-assessment for.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Label Buster

Label Buster is a step-by-step guide to help you identify information you need to create a food label that meets Australian requirements. At the end of Label Buster, you will generate:

  • a product sheet you can give to a printer to design a label for you
  • an example of what your food label should look like.

The Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (the Food Standards Code) sets the standards for food labelling in Australia. Significant penalties apply in Queensland under the Food Act 2006 (the Act), for non-compliance with the Food Standards Code.

Did you know

Labels must have the same information whether you sell your product once at a market stall, or regularly to a supermarket.

Who can use Label Buster?

Label Buster is designed for small to medium food businesses. If your food has complex labelling requirements, such as infant formula, sports supplements or alcohol, the tool does not provide all the information you need, and you are recommended to seek professional legal advice from a food labelling consultant.

Before you start

To use Label Buster, you will need:

Up to 1 hour - if you are familiar with food labelling requirements.

Up to 2 hours - if you have never made a food label before.

You will need information about your food, such as:

  • ingredients
  • use-by or best-before dates
  • any storage conditions or directions for use

The questions marked with a * must be completed. Other questions are optional.

Did you know

Label Buster will provide you with food labelling information to help you to comply with the Food Standards Code. After you finish Label Buster, you will need to include other mandatory requirements for a Nutrition Information Panel , weights and measures , and Country of origin labelling. Health Star Rating is a voluntary scheme you can choose to add to your food.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Terms of use

Please read and accept the terms of use before using Label Buster

  • Terms and conditions
  • Privacy statement
  • Disclaimer
  • Copyright

Warning

This tool does not meet all your legislative requirements, only those relating to the Food Standards Code. You will need to include other requirements on your food label, such as country of origin labelling.

It is your responsibility to ensure all the information on your food label is true and correct.

Queensland Health respects your right to privacy in using Label Buster. Any information you give will be handled by Queensland Health in accordance with the Information Privacy Act 2009.

No personal information is stored when you use Label Buster. For information about how Queensland Health protects your personal information, or to learn about your right to access your personal information, please see our website at www.health.qld.gov.au

Please note that our terms of use may change over time.

Label Buster is current as of June 2020 and shows information up to and including amendment number 192 of the Food Standards Code. It is recommended that you refer to the most current version of the Food Standards Code for full details and note any changes.

Your use of this website is your agreement to our terms and conditions.

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Label Buster
HTML
components.content:
About food labels

Select on the food label sections below to learn about labels.

|

Food labels must show the name of the food to help identify the food.

The name and description of the food must reflect its true nature. For example, strawberry yoghurt must contain strawberries. If the yoghurt contained strawberry flavouring rather than real fruit, then the name would need to indicate that it is strawberry-flavoured yoghurt.

If the name of the food does not reflect its true nature, then you must include a description of the true nature on the label. For example, Lukes Hots Sauce (red chilli pepper sauce).

To help customers identify where food has come from or to use for a food recall when food is unsafe, a food label must include the following business details:

  • name of the business supplying the food
  • business address in Australia or New Zealand, or a description of the location, of the premises where the business is being operated. A postal address cannot be used.

The National Measurement Institute is responsible for making sure food is measured and weighed correctly, and that the food is labelled with the correct weight and unit.

For example, food labelled as being 500g should weigh 500g and use the metric system of grams (g), kilograms (kg), millilitres (mL), litres (L), etc.

Visit the NMI website for more information on how to comply with the laws around weights and other measures.

Food packaged with a shelf life of 2 years or less must show a date mark.

Foods that should be eaten before a certain date for health and safety reasons must be labelled with a use-by date. Otherwise, a best-before date is required if the food has a shelf life of less than 2 years. Although it may be safe to eat the food after the best-before date, the food may have lost quality or some nutritional value.

Bread with a shelf-life of less than 7 days, can use a baked-for date or baked-on date instead of a best-before date.

The lot identification means a number or other information that identifies where the food was made and the batch it was part of. Often the date mark, name and address of the manufacturer meets this requirement.

Storage conditions
To keep food until its best-before or use-by date include storage conditions on your label.

Directions for use
A food label must have directions on how to use or prepare the food if needed for health and safety reasons.

A food label must contain a list of ingredients. The Food Standards Code has rules that describe how each ingredient must be listed, what it is called, and how it is formatted.

To help consumers avoid foods that are not safe for them to eat due to health conditions they may have, the Food Standards Code lists mandatory advisory statements, warning statements and allergen declarations that must be shown on a food label depending on the type of food and its ingredients.

The nutrition information panel (NIP) shows the number of servings in the package and the average amounts in a serving of food and per 100 grams (or 100 millilitres) of food for:

  • energy (in kilojoules)
  • protein
  • fat (including saturated fat)
  • carbohydrates (including sugars)
  • sodium

If a nutrition, health or related claim is made, the NIP must also show the amount of nutrient or substance. For example: the amount of calcium must be shown in the nutrition information panel if a claim about calcium is made.

There are strict requirements about claims that can be made and how they should be written on a label.

Nutrition content claims are claims about the content of certain nutrients or substances in a food. For example, contains calcium.

Health claims refer to a relationship between food and health. For example, calcium for bone and teeth.

<small class="hint">
    A novel food is a food or component that does not have a history of human consumption in Australia or New Zealand. This includes food that is typically not considered food, or a food made from processes not previously applied to food.
</small>

Seek professional advice

Thank you for your interest in Label Buster. Unfortunately, Label Buster does not provide labelling information for novel foods.

Novel foods require pre-market clearance before the food can be sold. We recommend you seek professional advice from a food labelling consultant to prepare your food label.

Making voluntary about your food is very complex and you are recommended to seek professional advice.

Please note, that about your food has other requirements such as additional information in your nutritional information panel and requirements under Australian Consumer Law.

You can only continue using Label Buster if you choose not to make a claim about your product.

components.content:
Food name and description

The purpose of a is to correctly describe what the food is. It cannot mislead the customer.

The Food Standards Code has rules on what you can name your food.

Food with extra requirements

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Business details

Food labels must include the business details (name and address) of the supplier on the label. A supplier is a business which packs, manufactures, sells or imports food. Business details help consumers, other businesses and government agencies know who to contact in the event of a complaint or food recall.

components.label: Business name
components.description: This is the name of the food business that is the supplier, manufacturer, packer, vendor or importer of the food.

components.label: Business Address
components.description: A business address is the street address, or a description of the location, of the premises, where the business is operating in Australia.  A post office box or similar is not allowed.

components.content:
Date marks

Foods that should be eaten before a certain date for health and safety reasons must be labelled with a use-by date. Other food that should be eaten in 2 years must have a best-before date.

components.legend:
Does your food have a shelf life of more than 2 years? *
For example:
  • Apricot jam in a bottle that has been heat treated
  • Canned peaches

HTML
components.content:
No date mark is required

No date marking information is required for a food with a shelf life of more than 2 years.

Manufacturers can choose to label this food with a packed-on date as a means of

components.content:
Best-before, baked-on or baked-for date

Bread with a shelf life of less than 7 days can be labelled using either a:

components.legend:
Does your food need to be eaten before a certain date because of health and safety? *
For example:
  • Food that may contain bacteria that will grow at fridge temperatures (e.g.: Listeria)
  • Perishable ready-to-eat food that will spoil (become mouldy, rancid or soured) before it becomes unsafe (e.g.: deli salads, prepared salads).
components.label:
Does your food need to be eaten before a certain date because of health and safety? *
For example:
  • Food that may contain bacteria that will grow at fridge temperatures (e.g.: Listeria)
  • Perishable ready-to-eat food that will spoil (become mouldy, rancid or soured) before it becomes unsafe (e.g.: deli salads, prepared salads).

Does your food need to be eaten before a certain date because of health and safety? *
For example:
  • Food that may contain bacteria that will grow at fridge temperatures (e.g.: Listeria)
  • Perishable ready-to-eat food that will spoil (become mouldy, rancid or soured) before it becomes unsafe (e.g.: deli salads, prepared salads).
HTML
components.content:
Use-by date

These foods must be labelled with a because they may become unsafe to eat after the use-by date has passed. A food may look, smell and taste ok but be unsafe to eat.

Best-before date

A is required for all foods with a shelf life of 2 years or less that do not need a The best-before date is the date up to which the food remains with good appearance, smell and taste, and keeps any qualities for which a claim has been made.

components.label: What type of date mark do you need for your food? *

values.label: <button data-accordion-item="what-date-mark" class="accordion-btn">       Do not need a date mark     </button>

components.label: HTML
components.content:
What is the date for the food?
The date will usually be in the of:
  • dd/mm/yyyy (e.g.: 15/3/2020) for food with a shelf life of 3 months or less, or
  • mmm/yyyy (e.g.: Apr 2021) for food with a shelf life of more than 3 months.

Leave this question blank if the food is not packaged or does not need a date mark.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Lot identifications
helps identify food. If using your date mark, leave blank or enter a batch number below.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Storage and use

Storage conditions describe how to keep food until its best-before or use-by date.

Directions for use are instructions for how to prepare the food so that it is ready to eat.

Storage conditions

Select the for your food. If your food has specific storage conditions to make sure it will keep until the best-before or use-by date, then you must include these on the label. Examples of some storage conditions have been included. You may select none, or one or more of these, depending on your requirements.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Ingredients

A food label must contain a list of ingredients that have been used to make the food. This is also known as the statement of ingredients.

components.legend: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (<button data-accordion-item="char-ingredient" class="accordion-btn">characterising ingredients</button> )?
components.label: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (characterising ingredients)?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint">For example: strawberries in strawberry jam, meat in a meat pie. </small>

components.label: Do you mention an ingredient, category of ingredients or a part of the food in the name on the label (<button data-accordion-item="char-ingredient" class="accordion-btn">characterising ingredients</button> )?
HTML
components.content:
Characterising ingredients

Food labels must show the percentage of the characterising ingredients in the food. The Food Standards Code provides details on how should be calculated and shown.

For example: The ingredient list would show the strawberries in strawberry jam as: Strawberries (23%).

components.legend: Do you use any <button data-accordion-item="comp-ingredient" class="accordion-btn"> compound ingredients </button>  to make your food?
components.label: Do you use any compound ingredients to make your food?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> A compound ingredient is any ingredient that is made from two or more ingredients. For example: chocolate chips in a muffin, tomato paste on a pizza. </small>

components.label: Do you use any compound ingredients to make your food?
HTML
components.content:
Compound ingredients

If a food contains that contribute 5% or more to the final food, then all the ingredients and additives in that compound ingredient must be declared. If a food contains a compound ingredient that contributes less than 5% to the final food, then only allergens and food additives require listing.

For example: The ingredient list would show the dark chocolate chips in a muffin as: dark chocolate chips [sugar, cocoa mass, cocoa butter, emulsifier (soy lecithin), natural vanilla flavour]

components.legend: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an     <button data-accordion-item="alt-ingredient" class="accordion-btn"> alternative ingredient  </button> to make your food?
components.label: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an alternative ingredient to make your food?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> This includes a food ingredient or additive that is replaced with another food or additive that serves the same function. For example: sultanas or raisins in a protein ball. </small>

components.label: Do you sometimes replace an ingredient with an alternative ingredient to make your food?
HTML
components.content:
Alternative ingredients

, including food additives, must be declared.

For example: The ingredient list would show: sultanas or raisins.

components.legend: Do you want to list an ingredient with a <button data-accordion-item="generic-name" class="accordion-btn"> generic name</button>?
components.label: Field Set
HTML
components.content:
Generic names may be used to describe the ingredient.

Cheese, cocoa butter, crystallised fruit, fruit, gum bases, herbs, meat, milk protein, poultry meat, spices and vegetables can be used as a generic name without any conditions.

, , , , , , , and have other requirements.

For example: Apple, pear and peach listed as fruit in a fruit pie.

components.label: Do you want to list an ingredient with a generic name?
HTML
components.content:
Generic Names

are specified in the Food Standards Code.

For example: The ingredient list could show the ingredients apple, pear and peach as either:

  • Fruit, or
  • Fruit (apple, pear, peach)

components.legend: Does your food contain any         <button data-accordion-item="food-additive" class="accordion-btn">food additives </button>?
components.label: Does your food contain any food additives?
HTML
components.content: <small class="hint"> For example: Food colours, flavours, preservatives, sweeteners, thickeners, etc. </small>

components.label: Does your food contain any food additives?
HTML
components.content:
Food additives

The substance (including a vitamin or mineral) used as a food additive must be declared.

The Food Standards Code specifies how to list in the ingredient list. This includes a list of class names and codes to use for specific food additives.

For example: The ingredient list would show the yellow food colouring tartrazine as either:

  • Colour (tartrazine), or
  • Colour (102)

components.legend: Does your food contain any         <button data-accordion-item="exempt-ingredient" class="accordion-btn">exempt ingredients </button> that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
components.label: Does your food contain any exempt ingredients that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
HTML
components.content:
For example:

  • A substance or food that is used as a processing aid.
  • An ingredient of a flavouring substance.
  • An ingredient such as water or alcohol, that is completely removed during the manufacture of the food.
  • Added water that forms part of broth, brine or syrup.

components.label: Does your food contain any exempt ingredients that do not need to be included in a statement of ingredients?
HTML
components.content:
Exempt ingredients

do not need to be included in the ingredient list.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Statements

Some foods or ingredients may be harmful to some people who are allergic or sensitive. These foods or ingredients must be written on the label no matter how small the amount and may also need a warning statement.

Allergen declarations

Select any food or ingredient in your food from the list below.

components.label:
Cereals containing gluten
For example, wheat, rye, barley, oats and spelt and their hybridised strains other than:
  • where these substances are present in beer and spirits; or
  • glucose syrups that are made from wheat starch and that:
    • have been subject to a refining process that has removed gluten protein content to the lowest level that is reasonably achievable; and
    • have a gluten protein content that does not exceed 20 mg/kg; or
  • alcohol distilled from wheat

Fish
Except for isinglass derived from swim bladders and used as a clarifying agent in beer or wine
Milk</br><small class="hint">Other than alcohol distilled from whey </small>

Soybeans
Other than:
  • soybean oil that has been degummed, neutralised, bleached and deodorised
  • soybean derivatives that are a tocopherol or a phytosterol
Sulphites added in concentrations of 10mg/kg or more

Tree nuts
Other than coconut from the fruit of the palm Cocos nucifera.

Your label information

Congratulations! You have completed all the steps in Label Buster.

Using your responses to each question, Label Buster has generated a product sheet and an example food label.

Label Buster is a brief guide to help you understand your labelling requirements. You may choose to get advice from a labelling consultant to make sure that your label complies with the Food Standards Code.

On this page, you will find:

  • Product sheet
  • Example food label
  • Legibility requirements
  • Exemptions
  • Download or email your summary
  • Need to update your label?

Product Sheet

You can take this information to a printer or graphic designer to create a label or use your own tools/templates. When creating your food label, you must ensure you meet the legibility requirements , such as minimum type size.

Claims

Health star rating Information on how to calculate and display a voluntary health star rating can be found at the health star rating system website.

Legibility requirements

All required words, statements, expressions or designs provided on a food label must be in English, be legible, and be prominent so as to contrast distinctly with the background of the label.

Information in other languages is permitted, provided it does not negate or contradict the English information.

No specific print type or size is defined for general labelling requirements, however:

  • warning statements must be in a type size of at least 3mm (or 1.5mm on small packages)
  • a print size is prescribed in the Food Standards Code for some foods where a required statement must be shown (e.g. infant formula).

Exemptions

All of the food label information needs to be included on your food label, except for:

  • Food sold in small packages
  • Food with one ingredient

There are extra requirements for:

  • Food sold from a vending machine
  • Food sold in a hamper

Your label information summary

Download your label information summary. This summary includes your product sheet and an example of what your label could look like.

components.label:
If you prefer, we can send you your self-assessment summary by providing an email address below.

Email

Depending on your email provider, personal information may be transferred outside of Australia. By providing your email address, you voluntarily agree to this transfer.
HTML
components.content:
Need to update your food label?

If you would like to update details in your food label, such as different flavours or ingredients, you can go back and update your answers by clicking on the relevant step. You can then regenerate your label with these new details.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Store food

When food is not being used, it must be kept so it does not become contaminated.

  • how to use different chemicals
  • where to clean
  • how to take apart equipment such as food processors to clean and sanitise them correctly.

Before you start

To complete this topic, you should think about:

  • How long you store food for?
  • Is your food protected when it is stored?
  • How do you separate food to be disposed?
  • How do you make sure food for disposal is not used?
  • What single use items do you have in your food business?
  • How do you store the single use items?

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Terms of use

Please read and accept the terms of use before using the Know Your Food Business self-assessment tool

  • Terms and Conditions
  • Privacy statement
  • Disclaimer
  • Copyright

Queensland Health respects your right to privacy in using Know Your Food Business self-assessment tool. Any information you give will be handled by Queensland Health in accordance with the Information Privacy Act 2009.

For information about how Queensland Health protects your personal information, or to learn about your right to access your personal information, please see out website at www.health.qld.gov.au

Please note that our terms of use may change over time. Your use of this website is your agreement to our terms and conditions.

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Store food

components.legend: Are storage areas clean and not overcrowded?
components.label: Are storage areas clean and not overcrowded?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  Your storage areas should look, smell and feel clean.
</small>

components.label: Are storage areas clean and not overcrowded?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must protect your food from contamination. Food can become contaminated from chemicals, bacteria, dust or pests.

components.legend: Are storage areas free from pests?
components.label: Are storage areas free from pests?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must protect your food from contamination.

We recommend you:

  • Have regular pest control done and keep receipts for each time it is done.
  • Regularly check for signs of pests (e.g.: mouse poo, spider webs). Call your pest control technician if you need extra treatment.
  • Check for pest entry points (e.g.: holes in walls, gaps under doors).

The factsheet at the end of the topic has easy steps to help you store your food safely.

components.legend: Is food protected from contamination?
components.label: Is food protected from contamination?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • food is covered or packaged
  • food safe containers are used
  • food and equipment are not stored on the floor or in toilet facilities
  • food is stored away from chemicals

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must protect your food from contamination.

The factsheet at the end of the topic has easy steps to help you store your food safely.

components.legend: Is food stored as directed, so that food is fresh and safe to use?
components.label: Is food stored as directed, so that food is fresh and safe to use?
HTML
components.content:
For example:
  • food is stored in freezer or fridge
  • food is stored in air-tight containers
  • food is protected from environmental conditions, such as: humidity, temperature and light. For example, dry foods exposed to humidity may absorb the moisture and become unsuitable.

components.label: Is food stored as directed, so that food is fresh and safe to use?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Different food will have different storage conditions. We recommend that you check the storage instructions to see how you can keep your food safe and suitable to use.

You can find storage instructions:

  • on the food package
  • attached to the food package
  • in documentation provided by the supplier.

The factsheet at the end of the topic has easy steps to help you store your food safely.

components.legend: Is your fridge set to less to 5C?
components.label: Is your fridge set to less to 5C?
Is your fridge set to less to 5C?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Potentially hazardous food must be stored at 5C or below to limit the growth of food poisoning bacteria or toxins.

Further information about potentially hazardous food, including how to store and handle it, can be found in the factsheet at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you keep high risk food for less than 24 hours?
components.label: Do you keep high risk food for less than 24 hours?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  Some examples of high risk foods are: raw egg foods such as aioli, mayonnaise
  or mousse.
</small>

components.label: Do you keep high risk food for less than 24 hours?
HTML
components.content:
Well done

It is important to only keep high risk foods for a short time. Some types of bacteria can grow even when the food is refrigerated.

High risk foods should be thrown out each day. We recommend that you make a fresh batch of high risk food every day.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may be unsafe and may cause food poisoning.

It is important to only keep high risk foods for a short time. Some bacteria can grow even when the food is refrigerated.

We recommend that you:

  • Make a fresh batch of high risk food each day.
  • Throw out high risk foods at the end of each day.
  • Label foods with a date that it was opened or made, so that you can keep track of how long each item has been stored for.
  • Follow the storage instructions from your supplier.

components.legend: Does frozen food stay frozen during storage?
components.label: Does frozen food stay frozen during storage?
Does frozen food stay frozen during storage?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Frozen food must stay frozen hard while it is being stored. Food that has thawed can still be used as chilled food, but it should not be refrozen.

You may have a problem with your freezer if your food shows signs of thawing while it is being stored. We recommend that you repair or replace your freezer if it does not maintain the correct temperature to keep food frozen.

components.legend: Do you have a thermometer that is accurate to within 1C (either above or below)?
components.label: Do you have a thermometer that is accurate to within 1C (either above or below)?
Do you have a thermometer that is accurate to within 1C (either above or below)?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

All food businesses must have a thermometer that is accurate to +/-1 C. This allows staff to make sure your food is stored at the right temperature.

Accurate thermometers can be purchased from catering or kitchen supply stores.

Further information on thermometers and how to calibrate them is included in the example procedure at the end of the topic.

components.legend: Do you check your fridge and freezer temperatures?
components.label: Do you check your fridge and freezer temperatures?
Do you check your fridge and freezer temperatures?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must store food at the correct temperature to prevent food poisoning.

We recommend that you:

  • Check your fridge and freezer each morning to make sure there wasnt a power failure during the night.
  • Regularly check the fridge and freezer temperature to make sure that you are storing food safely.

components.legend: Do you rotate stock to make sure you use the oldest product first?
components.label: Do you rotate stock to make sure you use the oldest product first?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint">
  For example: first in, first out principle
</small>

components.label: Do you rotate stock to make sure you use the oldest product first?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Stock rotation means that you use products with the earliest dates first.

Stock rotation helps reduce stock loss caused: by:

  • food expiring past the use-by date
  • food not being the best quality after the best-before date.

components.legend: Do you store raw food separately from ready-to-eat foods?
components.label: Do you store raw food separately from ready-to-eat foods?
HTML
components.content:
For example: raw food, like meat and seafood, are stored:
  • on a shelf below the ready-to-eat food
  • in a separate storage area

components.label: Do you store raw food separately from ready-to-eat foods?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Storing raw and read-to-eat food together can contaminate the ready-to-eat food. This may cause food poisoning. You must separate these foods.

components.legend: Do you keep food for disposal separate from other food?
components.label: Do you keep food for disposal separate from other food?
Do you keep food for disposal separate from other food?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must keep food that you are getting rid of separate and clearly marked from other food. This is so that you dont accidentally sell or use this food.

A separate storage area is not required, but a clearly labelled shelf or container is helpful.

components.legend: Do you store single use items to protect them from contamination?
components.label: Do you store single use items to protect them from contamination?
HTML
components.content:
Single use items include:
  • disposable gloves
  • drinking straws
  • plastic cutlery (like knives and forks)
  • disposable takeaway containers, wrappers and packaging

components.label: Do you store single use items to protect them from contamination?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You must prevent single use items from being contaminated while being stored. This includes single use items that customers can access (e.g.: straws).

Some ways to protect single use items from contamination include:

  • store off the floor
  • store in protective packaging or containers
  • store away from chemicals
  • store away from animals, pests and children
  • store ready to use cups, containers and cutlery upside down.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Summary

Thank you for taking the time to complete the Store food self-assessment.

A self-assessment summary has been generated from your responses to each question. From this page you can:

  • View resources for more information about this topic
  • Download a summary of your self-assessment
  • Email a summary of your self-assessment
  • Start another next self-assessment topic

Contact your local council if you would like further information or resources for your food business.

Resources

Below is a list of resources that you can view for more information about this topic.

Information and advice about temperature requirements for food and how to keep food under temperature control.

Go to website

Information and advice about keeping potentially hazardous food at safe temperatures.

Calibrating thermometers

A procedure to calibrate a thermometer

Download the calibrating thermometers procedure DOC 122 KB

Your self-assessment summary

Download your self-assessment summary.

components.content:
Topics to complete

There are still other topics you may wish to complete your self-assessment for.

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Transport food

You must transport food in a way to keep the food safe. Transport includes moving food from one place to another:

  • within the same premises (e.g. between wards in an aged card facility)
  • to another premises (e.g.: from your kitchen to a market stall or customers home)

You will need to plan how and when you transport your food, so that food is not contaminated during delivery. Your plan will need to consider:

  • delivery and dispatch times
  • the vehicle used to deliver the food
  • access to premises
  • a suitable place for the food to be loaded and unloaded.

Before you start

To complete this topic you should think about:

  • your delivery and dispatch times
  • the vehicle used to transport the food
  • is the food protected during transport?
  • is food transported under temperature control?

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Terms of use

Please read and accept the terms of use before using the Know Your Food Business self-assessment tool

components.label: I have read and accept the terms of use for Know Your Food Business
HTML
components.content: Transport food

components.legend: Do you protect your food from contamination during transport?
components.label: Do you stop pests from entering your food business?
HTML
components.content:
For example, the food is:
  • covered or packaged separately
  • packed to prevent damage
  • kept away from items such as chemicals, pet food or fuel.

components.label: Do you protect your food from contamination during transport?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

Your food may be contaminated during transport.

At the end of the topic, there are links to resources and training about how prevent the food contamination during transport. We recommend you share these resources with your staff.

components.legend: Are transport vehicles clean and in a good state of repair?
components.label: Are transport vehicles clean and in a good state of repair?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint"> Note: Transport vehicles include shopping trolleys and shopping baskets.
</small>

components.label: Are transport vehicles clean and in a good state of repair?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

All transport vehicles must be clean and working properly. For example, if a vehicle is used to transport chilled food, the refrigeration unit must be working.

components.legend: Is frozen food kept frozen solid during transport?
components.label: Is frozen food kept frozen solid during transport?
Is frozen food kept frozen solid during transport?
HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Warning!

If stated by the manufacturer, frozen food must remain frozen solid at all times including during transport. If the food starts to thaw, it can still be used as chilled food but must not be refrozen.

components.legend: Do you transport potentially hazardous food in temperature danger zone?
components.label: Do you transport potentially hazardous food in temperature danger zone?
HTML
components.content:
<small class="hint"> The temperature danger zone is between 5C and 60C.
</small>

components.label: Do you transport potentially hazardous food in temperature danger zone?
HTML
components.content:
Warning!

You should limit the time that you keep food in the temperature danger zone. This will help to stop bacteria and toxins from growing in your food.

If food is being transported long distances, or on hot days, we recommend that you use a refrigerated vehicle to keep food cold. For short distances, insulated containers may be enough to keep the food hot or cold.

You must be able to show that you transport food safely, including limiting the time that food is in the temperature danger zone.

The 2-hour/4-hour rule helps you to show that your food is safe. See the fact sheet and template record at the end of this topic for more information on the 2-hour/4-hour rule.

components.label: HTML
components.content: Well done

components.label: HTML
components.content:
Summary

Thank you for taking the time to complete the Transport food self-assessment.

A self-assessment summary has been generated from your responses to each question. From this page you can:
